sources: Lerer 2024 SSRN 5402461; INDEC labor statistics 2023; ILO Argentina profile
notes: Law 14250 (1953) established automatic extension of collective agreements beyond expiry. Constitutionalized in 1957 reform Art 14bis. Captured 3.2% of wage mass via mandatory contributions. Beneficiaries: 580K union officials/delegates. Cost bearers: 12M workers (diffuse, invisible payroll deduction). Veto players: CGT, political parties dependent on union support, judiciary. No sunset clause. Identity: Central to Peronist founding ideology (Art 14bis as 'social constitution'). Electoral: Peronism unviable without union machine (1983-2023 evidence). Survival: Memeplex ontologically dependent (justicialismo = workers + unions).

sources: Constitución Nacional 1994 Art 75 inc 2; Ley 23548; Auditoría General de la Nación 2022
notes: Federal tax revenue sharing system. Automatic distribution (no annual budget approval). Constitutionalized 1994 with 6-year maturation. Captured 4.8% of GDP via provincial bureaucracies. Concentrated: 850K provincial employees. Diffuse: 38M taxpayers (invisible consumption tax pass-through). Veto players: 24 provinces + federal government. No sunset, no coordination mechanism (requires unanimous provincial consent). Weak identity linkage (technocratic, not ideological). High judicial entrenchment (Art 75 can't be amended without 2/3 + provinces).

sources: Kaiser Family Foundation 2023; CBO scoring 2010-2023; NFIB v Sebelius 567 US 519
notes: Obamacare. Ordinary legislation (not constitutional). No prior maturation. Rent capture: 1.2% of healthcare spending via exchanges/Medicaid expansion. Beneficiaries: 18M insured via exchanges. Cost: 155M taxpayers (visible via tax subsidies). Veto players: President, Senate, House, Supreme Court, states (Medicaid expansion). Coordination exists (federal supremacy). No sunset but annual appropriations. Identity: Moderate Democratic platform (not existential). Survival: Democrats existed pre-ACA, would survive post-ACA. Low crystallization: Repeatedly challenged (2012, 2015, 2017, 2021).

sources: SSA Historical Statistics 2023; Pierson 'Dismantling the Welfare State?' 1994; Patashnik 'Reforms at Risk' 2008
notes: Social Security Act 1935. Constitutionalized via judicial interpretation (Helvering v Davis 1937). Automatic COLA since 1975. Rent capture: 2.1% administrative costs + trust fund interest. Concentrated: 67M beneficiaries (AARP political machine). Diffuse: 185M workers (visible payroll tax but normalized). Veto players: President, both chambers, courts, AARP. No sunset (perpetual entitlement). Identity: Core to New Deal liberalism founding myth. Electoral: Democratic coalition relies on seniors. Survival: Credible commitment device - party brand tied to 'saving Social Security'. Third rail politics.

sources: Chevron USA Inc v NRDC 467 US 837; Loper Bright v Raimondo 144 S Ct 2244 (2024 overruling)
notes: Judicial deference to agency interpretation. Zero legislative maturation (pure judicial doctrine). Low rent capture (0.15% - regulatory capture benefits). Concentrated: 125K federal regulators. Diffuse: 280M citizens (invisible administrative costs). Veto players: Supreme Court, agencies, Congress. Sunset: Overruled 2024 (40-year lifespan). Low visibility (technical doctrine). Weak identity linkage (administrative law technicality, not ideology). Note: Crystallized 1984-2024 but reversed - validates temporality of judicial doctrines without legislative/constitutional lock-in.

sources: Plebiscito rechazo 62% (4 sept 2022); Servel resultados oficiales; Centro de Estudios Públicos encuestas
notes: Failed constitutional replacement. Proposed text (convención constituyente 2021-2022). Zero rent capture (never enacted). Zero beneficiaries (aspirational). Cost: 19M voters saw high risk. High visibility (national referendum). Veto players: Popular sovereignty (50%+1 required). No entrenchment (rejected). Identity: Central to Frente Amplio founding narrative. Electoral: FA bet existence on approval. Survival: Memeplex existential (post-2019 estallido social legitimacy). Failed crystallization: Voter rejection killed institutional phenotype. CLI observed: 0.12 (attempted but failed - institutional abortion).

sources: Superintendencia de Pensiones 2023; DL 3500/1980; Reforma constitucional 2022 (fallida); Fundación Sol 2023
notes: Capitalized pension system (decree law dictatorship). Constitutionalized 1980 (Art 19 property right over contributions). Rent capture: 2.8% via AFP commissions. Concentrated: 95K financial sector employees. Diffuse: 8.5M contributors (visible discount but normalized). Veto players: Congress, Constitutional Court, AFPs, international investors. Weak sunset (attempted reforms 2006, 2008, 2014, 2022 all blocked). Identity: Core to Chicago Boys neoliberal founding myth. Electoral: Right-wing parties existentially tied. Survival: Memeplex identity (market ideology). Contested: 2019 protests demanded abolition but system survives.

sources: CLT Lei 5452/1943; CF 1988 Art 7-11; TST jurisprudência; IBGE PNAD 2023
notes: Labor code (Vargas era). Constitutionalized 1988 after 45-year maturation. Rent capture: 3.5% via union taxes + labor justice bureaucracy. Concentrated: 850K labor lawyers, judges, union officials. Diffuse: 95M formal workers (invisible payroll deduction). Veto players: 27 states + federal + labor courts + unions + political parties. No sunset. Identity: Core to trabalhismo/petismo founding myth. Electoral: PT unviable without union structure. Survival: Memeplex existential (PT = workers' party requires CLT framework). High judicial entrenchment (Art 7 rights can't be reduced).

sources: Estatuto Trabajadores Ley 8/1980; Reformas 2010, 2012, 2021; INE EPA 2023; CCOO/UGT
notes: Workers' Statute (post-Franco transition). Ordinary law (not constitutional). Zero prior maturation. Rent capture: 1.8% via union structures. Concentrated: 420K union officials + labor inspectors. Diffuse: 22M workers (visible social security contributions). Veto players: Parliament, unions, Constitutional Court, EU. Some sunset (reforms possible - evidence: 2012 Rajoy reform reduced protections). Identity: Moderate (linked to PSOE but not existential). Electoral: PSOE viable without statute. Survival: Not ontologically necessary (PSOE existed pre-1980, survived dictadura). Contested: Reformed multiple times (2010, 2012, 2021).

sources: Loi Aubry I (1998) et II (2000); DARES études 2019; Code du Travail L3121; Réformes Macron 2017
notes: 35-hour workweek (Aubry laws). Ordinary legislation. Zero prior maturation. Rent capture: 0.95% via hiring subsidies + compliance bureaucracy. Concentrated: 3.2M public sector (guaranteed 35h). Diffuse: 28M workers (visible schedule). Veto players: Parliament, unions, Constitutional Council, employers, EU. Sunset exists (2017 Macron reform allowed firm-level negotiations to exceed). Identity: Core to PS founding narrative (gauche plurielle). Electoral: PS heavily dependent on public sector unions. Survival: Moderate necessity (PS viable pre-2000). Contested: 2005, 2007, 2017 reforms weakened. Not fully crystallized - reversible.
